metadata.title: Peculiarities of fluoride activation of porphyrin and phthalocyanine catalysts by the example of zirconium and hafnium in the production of cyclic carbonates

Editor's choice paper Peculiarities of fluoride activation of porphyrin and phthalocyanine catalysts by the example of zirconium and hafnium in the production of cyclic carbonates Dedicated to Prof. Dr. Yuri N. Belokon on the occasion of his 85th birthday. Klim O. Biriukov Methodology Writing – review & editing a Svetlana A. Belova Methodology a Semyon V. Dudkin Methodology Writing – review & editing a Oleg I. A.N.Nesmeyanov Institute of Organoelement Compounds of Russian Academy of Sciences Vavilova St. 28, bld. 1, INEOS Moscow 119334 Russian Federation In this work, we have shown that fluoride additives can increase the catalytic activity of even 5- and 6-period metal complexes. Using tetraphenylporphyrin and phthalocyanine hafnium complexes as an example we were able to lower catalyst loading to 500 ppm. It was found out that after reaction tetraphenylporphyrin complex decomposed with the formation of meso‑tetraphenylporphyrin. Such process did not occur with the phthalocyanine complex. Moreover, in the presence of the fluoride additive hafnium tetrachloride showed high catalytic activity similar to both tetraphenylporphyrin and phthalocyanine comlpexes. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Porphyrins Phthalocyanines Demetallation Activation by fluoride Carbonate synthesis Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction Porphyrin and phthalocyanine complexes represent an important class of compounds [1] with a potential applications as single-molecule magnetism, conductive materials, organic field-effect transistors, materials for nonlinear optics, photosensitizers for photodynamic therapy [2] and in a number of other fields [3]. Moreover, porphyrin and phthalocyanine complexes with various transition and non-transition elements are actively studied as catalysts in different processes, in particular they can be applied for catalytic carbon dioxide fixation because of their unique properties, stability and modification capabilities [4–19]. The current trend for the development of metallophthalocyanine and metalloporphyrin catalysts is to create bifunctional systems. By introducing different cationic fragments into porphyrin and phthalocyanine structures, it is possible to obtain catalysts with high activity. For example, a phthalocyanine aluminum complex modified with four imidazole cationic groups makes it possible to obtain TON up to 1414 (yield 99%, catalyst loading 700 ppm) [17] Modified porphyrin bifunctional catalysts have even higher activity than their phthalocyanine counterparts do. For example, the tetraphenylporphyrin zinc complex modified with ammonium cations makes it possible to obtain TON up to 310,000 (yield 99%, catalyst loading 30 ppm) [9]. These systems have high activity, but the synthesis of such complex ligands requires several steps. Other approach to the design of active catalytic systems consists of the usage of simple commercially available compounds and activating cocatalysts. We decided to try to find effective activating cocatalysts instead of making complex adjustments to the catalyst structure. Using commercially available phthalocyanine aluminum chloride as an example, we were able to get TON up to 15,600 (50 ppm catalyst + cocatalyst, yield 78%) when using a fluoride additive, while the pure phthalocyanine aluminum chloride gave only TON 800 (250 ppm catalyst loading, 20% yield) [20]. We speculated that such activation could occur due to an increase of the Lewis acidity of aluminum center due to a strong bond with fluorine. This approach was found to be effective on third-period metals such as vanadium, nickel, and aluminum [20,21]. However, the question is the applicability of this approach to the metals from fifth and sixth period. Therefore, we began to study the activation of known complexes of heavier metals starting with hafnium (Scheme 1 ). Materials and methods Unless otherwise stated, all reagents were purchased from commercial suppliers and used without further purification. Isolation of products was performed using column chromatography (Macherey-Nagel, silica gel 0.04–0.063 mm). All details about particular chromatographic parameters are provided with the description of each compound. 1H, 13C{1H},19F spectra were recorded in CDCl3 or DMSO‑d6 on Bruker Avance 300, Bruker Avance 400, or Varian Inova 400 spectrometers. Chemical shifts are reported in parts per million relative to CHCl3 (7.26 and 77.16 ppm for 1H and 13C{1H} respectively) or DMSO‑d6 (2.5 and 39.52 ppm for 1H and 13C{1H} respectively). UV–Vis spectra of all the complexes in dichloromethane were recorded in the range 350–800 nm with an Agilent Cary 60 spectrophotometer. MALDI MS spectra were recorded on the AXIMA Confidence apparatus with 337 nm laser ionization using pyrene as a matrix. Analytical gas chromatography (GC) was performed using a Chromatec Crystal 5000.2NP gas chromatograph fitted with a flame ionization detector (He was used as the carrier gas) and a MS detector. Chromatec CR-5MS (30 m) capillary columns were used. Retention times (tR) and integrated ratios were obtained using Chromatec Analytic Software. GC settings for the yield determination using FID detector and CR5MS column: The injector temperature was 250 °C, split ratio of 75:1 at the moment of injection, the FID temperature was 250 °C. Column compartment temperature program: 100 °C for 5 min. Flow rate 1 mL/min, column CR-5MS. Retention time for 4-methyl-1,3-dioxolan-2-one (propylene carbonate, PC) is 3.68 min. Reactions under elevated pressure were carried out in glass vials in autoclaves made from either from stainless steel or titanium. The autoclave material had no effect on the reactions. All reactions were reproduced at least two times. Standard Deviation among 11 replicates is 4% General procedure A glass vial in a 10 mL stainless steel or titanium autoclave was charged with the prescribed quantity of the catalyst, cocatalyst, magnetic stirring bar and propylene oxide (100 mol%, 4.3 mmol). The autoclave was sealed and charged with the indicated pressure of CO2. The reactor was placed into a preheated oil bath. After the indicated time, the reactor was cooled down to room temperature and depressurized. The reaction mixture was transferred into a measuring flask and diluted with toluene to 5 mL, and then a sample of the resulting solution was analyzed by GC. Unless otherwise mentioned, the yields were determined by GC. All the experimental details, including the full optimization data, the procedures for the preparation of the particular compounds, the products characterization, and the description of the mechanistic experiments, are provided in the supporting information. Results and discussion In our previous research, we have shown that fluoride additives can readily activate aluminum phthalocyanine chloride. For a more thorough study of fluoride activation, we decided not to change many parameters at a time. Therefore, we took the phthalocyanine complex of heavier hafnium (PcHfCl2 ) as the first candidate. In this way, we hoped to minimize the contribution of the ligand to the metal activation issue. After that, we decided to proceed to close porphyrin systems using the example of the hafnium tetraphenylporphyrin complex (TPPHfCl2 ) (Fig. 1 ). These complexes are known, but, to the best of our knowledge, their catalytic properties in the CO2 fixation reaction have not been studied. We chose propylene oxide as the model substrate because of its relatively low reactivity in the reaction with carbon dioxide. Tetrabutylammonium triphenyldifluorosilicate (TBAT, [Bu4N][Ph 3SiF2]) was chosen as a fluoride additive because this compound is stable under normal conditions and soluble in different organic solvents. It is not hydroscopic like cesium fluoride and TBAF (tetrabutylammonium flouride). TBAT is easy to work with, especially at low catalyst loadings. We began our study by testing the catalytic activity of the compounds PcHfCl2 and TPPHfCl2 themselves and the fluoride additive separately. Expectedly, the complexes themselves showed no catalytic activity (Table 1 , entry 1,2). It is noteworthy that TBAT itself can catalyze this process, however, only 6% yield was obtained (Table 1, entry 3). PcHfCl2 and TPPHfCl2 in the presence of TBAT showed significantly higher catalytic activity, which exceeded the sum of individual activities of both TBAT and complexes (PcHfCl2 and TPPHfCl2 ) (Table 1, entry 4,5 vs entries 1–3). This confirms the synergistic effect between the hafnium compounds and the fluoride additive. Since the activation of hafnium compounds by fluoride was confirmed, we decided to continue the study using compound TPPHfCl2 , which showed a little bit higher activity than compound PcHfCl2 (Table 1, entry 4,5). To make sure that our catalytic system is exceptionally activated by fluoride, we decided to test the effect of the similar additive TBAC with heavier halogen atom (tetrabutylammonium chloride) (for more details see ESI). We observed sharp decrease in the yield compared to fluoride activation (entry 5 vs 6). In order to gain a better understanding of our system we investigated reaction mixtures containing PcHfCl2 / TPPHfCl2 and TBAT using MALDI-TOF. (for more details see ESI). We found species such as PcHfF2 + and TPPHfF+. Thus, we assumed that fluoride complexes formed in situ could catalyze the reaction. Since active catalytic particles can lose their activity during isolation not only due to decomposition, but also due to the possibility of formation of associates/polymer structures, all this can lead to a loss of catalyst activity. To check this assumption, we synthesized PcHfF2 and TPPHfF2 , isolated them, and tried to use them as catalysts. These complexes did not show any catalytic activity (Table 1, entries 7–8). Therefore, we believe that in situ activation with fluorides is not only easier from an experimental point of view, but also much more efficient for catalysis. During the analysis of the reaction mixtures containing compounds PcHfCl2 and TPPHfCl2 , we noticed that in the case of porphyrin TPPHfCl2 (Table 1, entry 5), partial demetallation with the formation of a free meso‑tetraphenylporphyrin base was observed (Scheme 2 a). This effect was exclusive to TBAT. Other additives did not lead to such result. (for more details see ESI) After this discovery, we decided to find out if a similar process is possible for porphyrin complexes of other metals, so we decided to take a similar complex of zirconium porphyrin TPPZrCl2 . Since zirconium and hafnium are in the same group, their compounds should have similar properties. Complex TPPZrCl2 showed low reactivity under reaction conditions in the presence of TBAT (Table 1, entry 9–10), however complex TPPZrCl2 showed similar demetalation in this reaction (Scheme 2b). No similar process was observed in the analysis of reaction mixtures with PcHfCl2 . No evidences of metal removal were detected. It is noteworthy that the more stable hafnium phthalocyanine complex PcHfCl2 (Scheme 2c) shows comparable activity with the disintegrating complex TPPHfCl2 . With these results in hands, we supposed that the catalytic activity of this system might be explained by the properties of the free ligand and/or hafnium salt. We checked the reactivity of the ligands themselves (H2TPP and H2Pc) and the simple hafnium salt (HfCl4 ·2THF) with presence of TBAT (Table 1, entries 11–16). Whereas the ligands (H2TPP and H2Pc) showed low catalytic activity (almost the same as TBAT, entry 12 vs. 5 and entry 14 vs 4), the salt HfCl4 ·2THF showed activity comparable to that of complexes PcHfCl2 and TPPHfCl2 (Table 1, entries 4–5 vs 15). We further optimized the catalytic system (for more details see ESI). Finally we tested the substrate scope of HfCl4 ·2THF+TBAT catalytic system in the synthesis of cyclic carbonates 2a-i from epoxides 1a-i and carbon dioxide (Scheme 3 ). Propylene oxide (1a), epichlorhydrin (2b) and buthylene oxide (1c) reacted with CO2 in high yields. Ether derivatives 1d-f were also excellent substrates under these conditions. Styrene oxide (1g) reacted with CO2 in moderate yield. Predictably, cyclopentene oxide (1h) and cyclohexene oxide (1i) were the least reactive substrates. We had to use 2500 ppm of HfCl4 ·2THF and TBAT to obtain 2h and 2i with good yields. Cyclopentene oxide (1h) gave cis-cyclohexene carbonate (2h) with an insignificant admixture of trans-cyclohexene carbonate. After this initial success, we decided to try to scale up the reaction (Scheme 4 ). Conclusions In conclusion, this paper further expands applicability of in situ fluoride activation from elements of third period to sixth period. Activity of various hafnium sources was significantly increased in presence of TBAT. While both tetraphenylporphyrin and phthalocyanine complexes show similar catalytic activity, their stability is rather different. It was shown that porphyrin complexes undergo demetalation process during catalytic reaction, however phthalocyanine complex remains unaffected. It is important to note that in the presence of TBAT, simple hafnium salt shows comparable activity to both phthalocyanine and tetraphenylporphyrin complexes, which may be useful for better understanding principles of fluoride activation and designing of new catalytic systems. coredata.dc:description: In this work, we have shown that fluoride additives can increase the catalytic activity of even 5- and 6-period metal complexes. Using tetraphenylporphyrin and phthalocyanine hafnium complexes as an example we were able to lower catalyst loading to 500 ppm. It was found out that after reaction tetraphenylporphyrin complex decomposed with the formation of meso‑tetraphenylporphyrin. Such process did not occur with the phthalocyanine complex. Moreover, in the presence of the fluoride additive hafnium tetrachloride showed high catalytic activity similar to both tetraphenylporphyrin and phthalocyanine comlpexes.
coredata.dc:title: Peculiarities of fluoride activation of porphyrin and phthalocyanine catalysts by the example of zirconium and hafnium in the production of cyclic carbonates
